item.content:encoded:
This post originates from iodomi.eu > published on 18th of August 2025.

Hiii and kindly welcome again. Today I'll be yapping about my latest experiences and why have I made a step back and went on Fedora Atomic (again, but Kinoite this time).

Why?

Using Fedora may seem obvious for numerous reasons for a security person, like me. Despite the fact that Fedora is not a very complicated distribution (I think it's kinda newb friendly) it has some good security measures f.e. SELinux as a default MAC, TPM2 lock, LUKS on btrfs, secure boot and more… But I still didn't address the "Atomic" part of the question. Well the key differences that make atomic distros so superior are read-only rootfs, safe package manager, containers, layered packages, deployements, etc. But for the most part, there's a distro I have already used, but didn't liked that much before - secureblue (it is also in lowercase lol).

What is secureblue?

secureblue is a security-focused desktop Linux distribution. It is generated with BlueBuild, using Fedora Atomic Desktop's base images. The goal of secureblue is to max out the security of Linux eliminating attack surface, increasing defense against exploits/vulnerabilities while avoiding sacrifising usability (for most). As they say it's mostly a distro for those who want to use Linux in the first place but also don't want to lose security. - based on their website's about. Basically it's a very good distro for my threat model.

But you'll be more vulnerable.

Is this a possiblity? Let's consider together. Fedora Atomic as a Linux distribution mostly focuses on things like containerization, reliablity and safety. all of the above are good traits, but there are also bad ones like using systemd, glibc and fixed release model. And what do I do about it - as a person who used OpenRC and musl? I have to say that I don't really care that much anymore. I want my system to work well and be secure which is accomplished by secureblue developers. I also think that secureblue gives much more security features than those I could apply by myself on Alpine. At the end of the day it's not only about init system, C library or release model (Alpine also had fixed), but more about hardening and preventing malicious use of existing software/hardware bugs/exploits.

Testing Plasma 6.4

I'm also moving away from Sway window manager, for now at least. As I was testing different desktop environments for a while. One desktop that caught my eye was exacly KDE. I enjoy their approach and convinience it gives. There are also some disadvantages f.e. too much bloat (which secureblue thankfully removes), highier resource usage, lower battery lifespan, etc. But on the bright side KDE is now securing privileged Wayland protocols since 6.4. This decision has meet with my apprication and I've waited for it for some time. I'll maybe go back to Sway someday, but for now I'm so sold :^)

Goodbye Alpine!

Finally the time has come to explain why have I made this drastic decision. To clear things out, I don't think that Alpine is a bad distro in any sense. I still love Alpine for its simplicity and minimalism, then why did I go on Fedora? - you may ask. Well I have my reasons. Alpine is not the best fit for desktop setups. And well it's obvious for most folks, even for a hardcore user like me, but it did not stop me in any sense. But I have to say it's sometimes annoying how I try to compile something, just to be greeted with compiler errors (mostly oriented about glibc which I don't have on Alpine ofc) that are sometimes just impossible to fix for an end user like me without hacking onto it. Well then how can you prevent this? Containers and gcompat. Did it solve the problem? No it didn't I tried fixing errors by running in container or with gcompat with basically no result. I think the worst case I had with this is trying to run Super Mario 64 decomp. So for some context me and my friend wanted to play sm64 on LAN together, so he tells me to compile the decomp, so well I go into it. How it ends? It ends on me reading a Makefile for half an hour, trying composing with docker (which almost worked out) and finally losing hope. It turned out that they hardcoded some things to only work with glibc systems. And don't even think that it was the first time I had problems like so, IT'S NOT THE FIRST TIME!!! Sometimes I also had problem with something not working just because I have OpenRC not systemd… In conclusion I was tired of troubleshooting every single thing that would take me minutes and not hours on a normal distro.

Thanks for listening to my distro rant, have a good day byeee!!!!
